A change in the price of a complement

Because his children now also have cell phones, Mr Dlamini buys more airtime per week.

Watch the following video clip to see the impact of a change in the price of a complement.

As a general rule we can state the following:

A decline in the price of a complementary product (cell phones) increases the quantity demanded of it as well as the demand for the complement (airtime).

An increase in the price of a complementary product (cell phones) decreases the quantity demanded of it as well as the demand for the complement (airtime).

Do the following activity to help you understand the impact of a change in the price of complements:
